Title: The shape that changed our world forever
Video: starts talking about yellow stop signs

I used to run laser trackers for inspection in a machine shop, they use a steel ball bearing with a retroreflector cut into it, the center of the retroreflector is the exact center of the sphere, which you manually place on the parts to be measured and the laser follows it, and based on the rotation angle of the head, elevation of the beam projector, and distance the laser beam travels (measured with an on-board interferometer) and then inputting that info into 3D software a 3D reconstruction of the part can be made, which can be compared to a perfect 3D model of the part in the software. By comparing the differences between the measured model and the 3D model, I would be able to determine if the parts our shop made were within tolerance and able to ship out to our customers. The retroreflector spheres were 1.5" inches in diameter and cost $2,500 dollars apiece, and I have no idea how they cut the flat surfaces inside to have the edges meet up as perfectly as they did and polish them as perfectly as they did, it looked like it was made from three precision ground and polished individual pieces then bonded together but they were cut from a solid ball bearing. Some kind of machining voodoo I guess.
For the first time in my life. Now I know why painting a car red costs so much more than any other color. It fades!!!

So, what exactly was the shape that changed the world? This video first notes that spherical beads do a good job of retroreflection but then notes that  the inside-corner mirror reflector does a better job, implying that it's not spheres but something different that's actual "The Shape". Yet then it goes on for the rest of the video about the reflective tapes, which it appears uses the spherical beads. I was expecting the video to go into some detail as to how the company mass-manufacture tiny shapes (not spheres) thqt employ that inside-corner mirror approach.

Very interesting but im curious about the manufacturing. How do you get thousands of very tiny 3 part mirrors at 90° into such a small space? Do the tiny mirrors ever break or loose reflectivity with time and weathering? Surely for anything that isnt using just glass beads, they must have a very interesting machine for aligning all the reflectors. Or maybe its just throwing in thoundands in there knowing some will inevitably face the right way by rule of numbers?

Cant exactly be just some dude in the back positioning them all with a pair of tweezers before putting down some layer of film or glue to keep them in place since their making entire rolls of the stuff for thousands of signs.

If anyone knows let me know. It is really interesting to me

Looks like 3M invented retroreflective tape in 1937, the year after the retroreflective cats eye was patented. Physically very different though even if they were trying to solve similar problems, durability meant the cats eye was used for the road surface markings and the 3M tape for signage. Until the 3M tape became durable enough for road markings at least.

I made retroreflective targets for laser electronic distance measuring, and they enable me to make 3D measurements to within about 1/8" from 200 feet away. Coupled with photogrammetry, I can take very accurate measurements using multiple images, including modelling an entire 1960s 30,000 square foot country club building inside and out. The targets are only 3/4" around. This is the identical technique used on JWST heat shield deployment tests.
In the military we'd use a red lense. It would be strong enough to read things up close but is less likely for an enemy to see it from a distance

It's all about the bending. While the statement that "there's no such thing as a straight line in Nature" has been endlessly attacked and disingenuously shifted to a ridiculous "there are straight lines in the circumference of a sphere" arguments, the simple, obvious fact is that round is where it's at. Whether it's optics or architecture, the very obvious fact is that the curve best describes everything.

I was driving at night in a thunderstorm right after getting my drivers license. I could see fine as the road was about to curve around a deep sinkhole partly filled with water. I guess there was a power outage because suddenly my headlights were the only lights. The road strips must not have had the retroreflectors for water because I couldn't see them at all. Plus my eyes were still acclimating to it being much darker. For a few seconds it was like I was in a black void. Meanwhile, there was a nice 30' drop into an alligator infested sinkhole somewhere out there. Then a car came at me and blinded me with their high beams and because of the unseen curve, I couldn't tell if I was in their lane or heading into the hole or ok. I think that was my scariest driving experience ever. I think it would be an excellent idea to mix both retroreflectors into all road stripes.

Oohh.... that explains a lot! I know here in Wisconsin, they were testing orange-colored lines too because of snowy conditions. I haven't seen them in a while, so I don't think it was a successful project... but as I'm getting older, it's getting harder to see at night but a nightmare when both night and rainy, and a lot of city streets could use touch up more than just the highways. I find myself just staying against the medium or the double-sided lines, slowly to get around when it's raining.

The reflector on the thumbnail is never mentioned in the video.  So it's worth mentioning here.  It is used is used in land surveying to reflect an infrared laser back to an electronic total station.  This is how we measure distances between points on the ground.

Interesting to know that you guys have retroreflection on the road lines, as Australia (or at least Sydney) doesn't have those. Instead we use something similar you see on the back of bikes (those red reflective things). Ours is "glued" inbetween the dotted lines for lanes we can cross/change-to (in yellow), and outside the solid lines (in red). So the red ones tell us how big the road is, and yellow tells us the lanes.

0:35 well, the rods do capture a tiny bit of red, since they extend to 640nm (according to the experiments by George Wald). And below 625nm, they still capture orange a bit more than red. So while it’s true that the rods are relatively insensitive to red, it’s incorrect to state that they don’t respond to red at all.

It should be federal LAW that major road lines and markings are pressure washed every year and repainted every 5 years with rain and dry reflective paint. This should go for intersection and other markings as well. Left turn guidance dashed lines are included. For large but less traveled roads and intersections, permanent reflector devices should be glued into the road so even if the lines get worn or dirty, the row of those reflectors will always remain. I hate hate hate when lines and markings are worn away or obscured by rain and grime. I visited my friend in Oklahoma with all the weird concrete roads, and damn near 80% of the lines and marks are gone. They just apparently decide on the fly what should happen where and play bumper cars if 2 people disagree on where a turning lane is. It's ridiculous. Here in Arizona, our roads melt and crack before major paint wear occurs. 🙄 You can see where you're supposed go, along with the 3 foot potholes and fissures that bubble your tire and pull your steering wheel all over the place. It was fun getting forced to ride in a parallel fissure back when I rode a motorcycle. 🙄 Not.

Ontario learned a hard lesson recently: DON'T make the WHOLE surface of a car registration plate retroreflective. They wanted fancy white-on-blue plates, so they decided the old way of painting over embossed retroreflective digits with a colour was passé. Guess what, the new plate got so much light reflected off of digits and background alike, that the number was unreadable in car headlights. No matter, they pressed ahead and installed a whole bunch, until police said "we can't read them, so stop!" The funny part is that all this was researched to death in Europe in late 1960s. That's why all wealthy countries switched from then-standard white-on-black, to color or black (non-retroreflective) on color or white (retroreflective) background. Best contrast! But in Ontario, politicians wanted "cool" and who cares what those engineers say. The only word that matters in government comes from moneyed people, not some pesky specialists who (yuck!) work for their daily bread.

Fun fact.  One of the first things that was left on the moon, on the Apollo 11 mission, was a retro reflector.  It is was left there so we can accurately measure the distance from the earth to the moon.  And with the right equipment you can use it to this day.  It is one of the indisputable proofs that we did in fact go to the moon.
What's the shape though?

LOVE that retroreflection is making it more into everyday knowledge. Celebrities sometimes use Retroreflective clothing to wash out photographs taken by the paparazzi with flash as the light from the flash bounces directly back to the camera. Also, Disney and similar theme parks are trying to use retroreflective surfaces to create illusions of holograms floating in space. Its complicated to explain without visuals, but it uses the Pepper's Ghost effect with a retroreflective surface to bounce the image back to appear floating in front of the reflection surface versus behind it. Imagine if the Haunted Mansion ghosts weren't some distance away from you in a scene, but in front of you floating with no scenery or elements around it. You can test this using 3D rendering software and it actually works, except the only downside at the moment is the quality of the image is dependent on the density of the retroreflective material. There are ways to cheat this but still nothing that has really resulted in HD images/holograms that I know of as yet!
